title: 105_s1485
content: The "Thurgood Marshall Commemorative Coin Act of 1997" authorizes the minting of 400,000 1 dollar silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper, weigh 26.73 grams, and have a diameter of 1.500 inches. The silver for minting will be sourced from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize Thurgood Marshall's tenure on the Supreme Court, with inscriptions of value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Supreme Court Historical Society, Marshall's family, and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize Thurgood Marshall's tenure on the Supreme Court and will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Supreme Court Historical Society, Marshall's family, and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design will also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single United States Mint facility within a 1-year period starting 90 days after the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. The Secretary shall promptly pay all surcharges from coin sales to the Historical Preservation Committee of the Supreme Court Historical Society for collecting and preserving the physical history of the Supreme Court, including research, acquisition of objects and documents, and preservation of historical documents, portraits, and furnishings for the benefit of the people of the United States. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the Supreme Court Historical Society's books and records related to expenditures paid from coin sales for historical preservation. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure that minting and issuing coins will not cost the government. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantees.
